{{Infobox saint |honorific-prefix=[[Servant of God]] |name = Dorothy Day |honorific-suffix=[[Oblate#Secular oblates|Obl.S.B.]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1897|11|8}} |death_date = {{Death date and age|1980|11|29|1897|11|8}} |feast_day = |venerated_in = [[Roman Catholic Church]] |image = Dorothy Day, 1916 (cropped).jpg |imagesize = 230px |caption = Dorothy Day in 1916 |birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] |death_place = [[Manhattan|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] |titles = Foundress and Lay Activist |beatified_date = |beatified_place = |beatified_by = |canonized_date = |canonized_place = |canonized_by = |attributes = |patronage = |major_shrine = |suppressed_date = |issues = |prayer = |prayer_attrib = }} {{Social Christianity}} {{Libertarian socialism|Christian Anarchism}} {{American socialism|Activists}} '''Dorothy Day''' {{post-nominals|post-noms=[[Oblate#Secular oblates|OblSB]]}} (November 8, 1897 – November 29, 1980) was an American journalist, [[social activist]], and [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] convert. Day initially lived a [[bohemianism|bohemian]] lifestyle before gaining fame as a social activist after her [[religious conversion|conversion]]. She later became a key figure in the [[Catholic Worker Movement]]<ref name=elie43>Elie (2003), p. 43</ref> and earned a national reputation as a [[political radicalism|political radical]],<ref name=elie433>Elie (2003), p. 433</ref> perhaps the most famous radical in [[Catholic Church in the United States|American Catholic Church]] history.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/day-by-day-a-saint-for-the-occupy-era |title=Day by Day; A Saint for the Occupy Era? |last1=Cannon |first1=Virginia |date=November 30, 2012 |website=The New Yorker |access-date=September 30, 2015}}</ref>
Day's conversion is described in her autobiography, ''[[The Long Loneliness]]''.<ref name=Benedict>{{cite web |url=http://w2.vatican.va/content/benedict-xvi/en/audiences/2013/documents/hf_ben-xvi_aud_20130213.html |title=General Audience, 13 February 2013 |last1=Pope Benedict XVI |date=February 13, 2013 |website=Vatican |access-date=September 30, 2015}}</ref><ref name=elie43>Elie (2003), p. 43</ref> Day was also an active journalist, and described her social activism in her writings. In 1917 she was imprisoned as a member of suffragist [[Alice Paul]]'s nonviolent [[Silent Sentinels]]. In the 1930s, Day worked closely with fellow activist [[Peter Maurin]] to establish the Catholic Worker Movement, a pacifist movement that combines direct aid for the poor and homeless with [[nonviolent direct action]] on their behalf. She practiced [[civil disobedience]], which led to additional arrests in 1955,<ref name=elie237>Elie (2003), pp. 236-237</ref> 1957,<ref name=elie279>Elie (2003), pp. 279</ref> and in 1973 at the age of seventy-five.<ref name=elie433>Elie (2003), p. 433</ref> As part of the Catholic Worker Movement, Day co-founded the ''[[Catholic Worker]]'' newspaper in 1933, and served as its editor from 1933 until her death in 1980. In this newspaper, Day advocated the Catholic economic theory of [[distributism]], which she considered a third way between capitalism and socialism.<ref>{{cite web|title = G.K. Chesterton and Dorothy Day on Economics:Neither Socialism nor Capitalism (Distributism)|url = http://cjd.org/2001/10/01/g-k-chesterton-and-dorothy-day-on-economicsneither-socialism-nor-capitalism-distributism/|website = cjd.org|accessdate = October 2, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title = The ChesterBelloc Mandate: Dorothy Day and Distributism|url = http://distributist.blogspot.com/2007/02/dorothy-day-and-distributism.html|accessdate = October 2, 2015}}</ref> [[Pope Benedict XVI]] used her conversion story as an example of how to "journey towards faith... in a secularized environment."<ref name=Benedict /> [[Pope Francis]] included her in a short list of exemplary Americans, together with [[Abraham Lincoln]], [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]], and [[Thomas Merton]], in his address before the [[United States Congress]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://w2.vatican.va/content/francesco/en/speeches/2015/september/documents/papa-francesco_20150924_usa-us-congress.html |title=Visit to the Joint Session of the United States Congress |last1=Pope Francis |date=September 24, 2015 |website=Vatican |access-date=September 30, 2015}}</ref> The Church has opened the cause for Day's possible [[canonization]], which was accepted by the [[Holy See]] for investigation. Due to this, the Church refers to her with the title of [[Servant of God]].
==Biography==
===Early years=== Dorothy May Day was born on November 8, 1897, in the [[Brooklyn Heights]] neighborhood of [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=American Prophets: Seven Religious Radicals and Their Struggle for Social and Political Justice|last=Raboteau|first=Albert J.|publisher=|year=2016|isbn=|location=|pages=64}}</ref> She was born into a family described by one biographer as "solid, patriotic, and middle class".<ref>{{cite book|last=Coles |first=Robert |title=Dorothy Day: A Radical Devotion|location=Reading, MA|publisher=Addison-Wesley|year=1987}}</ref> Her father, John Day, was a [[Tennessee]] native of [[Scots-Irish American|Irish]] heritage, while her mother, Grace Satterlee, a native of upstate New York, was of [[English people|English]] ancestry. Her parents were married in an [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] church in [[Greenwich Village]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Miller|first=William D.|title=Ray Rivera Lopez: A Biography|year=1982|publisher=Harper & Row|location=NY|pages=1–7}}</ref> She had three brothers and a sister. In 1904, her father, who was a sports writer devoted to horse racing, took a position with a newspaper in [[San Francisco]]. The family lived in [[Oakland, California]], until the [[San Francisco Earthquake of 1906]] destroyed the newspaper's facilities, and her father lost his job. From the spontaneous response to the earthquake's devastation, the self-sacrifice of neighbors in a time of crisis, Day drew a lesson about individual action and Christian community. The family relocated to [[Chicago]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Miller|first=William D.|title=Dorothy Day: A Biography|year=1982|publisher=Harper & Row |location=NY |pages=9–10, 13–4}}</ref>
Day's parents were nominal Christians who rarely attended church. As a young child, she showed a marked religious streak, reading the Bible frequently. When she was ten she started to attend Church of Our Saviour, an Episcopal church in the Lincoln Park neighborhood of Chicago, after its [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] convinced her mother to let Day's brothers join the church [[choir]]. She was taken with the [[liturgy]] and its music. She studied the [[catechism]] and was [[baptism|baptized]] and [[confirmation|confirmed]] in that church in 1911.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=14–5}}</ref>
Day was an avid reader in her teens, particularly fond of [[Upton Sinclair]]'s ''[[The Jungle]]''. She worked from one book to another, noting [[Jack London]]'s mention of [[Herbert Spencer]] in ''Martin Eden'', and then from Spencer to Darwin and Huxley. She learned about anarchy and extreme poverty from [[Peter Kropotkin]], who promoted a belief in cooperation in contrast to Darwin's competition for survival.<ref name="Miller 1982 27–8">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=William D.|title=Dorothy Day: A Biography|year=1982|publisher=Harper & Row|location=NY|pages=27–8}}</ref> She also enjoyed [[Russian literature]] in university, especially [[Fyodor Dostoevsky|Dostoevsky]], [[Leo Tolstoy|Tolstoy]], and [[Maxim Gorky|Gorky]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Long Loneliness: the autobiography of Dorothy Day|year=1981|publisher=Harper & Row|location=San Francisco|page=43}}</ref> Day read a lot of socially conscious work, which gave her a background for her future; it helped bolster her support for and involvement in social activism.
In 1914, Day attended the [[University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign]] on a scholarship. She was a reluctant scholar.<ref name="coles2"/> Her reading was chiefly in a Christian radical social direction.<ref name="coles2"/> She avoided campus social life, and supported herself rather than rely on money from her father, buying all her clothing and shoes from discount stores.<ref name="bulletin11-29-80">{{cite news | title = Dorothy Day dead at 83 | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1243&dat=19801201&id=s9ZYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yPYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4367,6238981 | work = [[The Bulletin (Bend)|The Bulletin]]| page = 61 | date = November 29, 1980}}</ref> She left the university after two years, and moved to [[New York City]].<ref name="coles2">Coles (1987), p. 2.</ref>
===Social activism=== She settled on the [[Lower East Side]] and worked on the staff of several Socialist publications, including [[The Liberator (magazine)|''The Liberator'']],<ref name="catholicworker022109">{{cite web | url = http://www.catholicworker.org/historytext.cfm?Number=4 | first = Tom | last = Cornell | title = A Brief Introduction to the Catholic Worker Movement | publisher = catholicworker.org | accessdate = February 21, 2009 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140314165158/http://www.catholicworker.org/historytext.cfm?Number=4 | archivedate = March 14, 2014 | df = mdy-all }}</ref> ''[[The Masses]]'', and ''[[New York Call|The Call]]''. She "smilingly explained to impatient socialists that she was 'a pacifist even in the class war.'"<ref>Vance, Laurence (December 4, 2006) [http://archive.lewrockwell.com/vance/vance98.html Bill Kauffman: American Anarchist], ''[[LewRockwell.com]]''</ref> Years later, Day described how she was pulled in different directions: "I was only eighteen, so I wavered between my allegiance to Socialism, [[Syndicalism]] (the [[Industrial Workers of the World|I.W.W.]]'s) and [[Anarchism]]. When I read [[Leo Tolstoy|Tolstoy]] I was an Anarchist. My allegiance to ''The Call'' kept me a Socialist, although a left-wing one, and my Americanism inclined me to the I.W.W. movement."<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|page=30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=Chapter 6 - New York|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/206.html|work=From Union Square to Rome|publisher=Dorothy Day Collection|accessdate=January 27, 2014}}</ref>
She celebrated the [[February Revolution]] in Russia in 1917, the overthrow of the monarchy and establishment of a reformist government.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=32–3}}</ref> In November 1917, she was arrested for picketing at the White House on behalf of women's suffrage as part of a campaign called the [[Silent Sentinels]] organized by [[Alice Paul]] and the [[National Women's Party]]. Sentenced to 30 days in jail, she served 15 days before being released, ten of them on a hunger strike.<ref>{{cite news|title=Suffrage Pickets Freed from Prison |accessdate=January 26, 2014 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/28/102379956.pdf |newspaper=New York Times |date=November 28, 1917}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Cat-and-Mouse Remedy for Hunger-Striking |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/29/102380265.pdf |accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times |date=November 29, 1917}}</ref>
She spent several months in Greenwich Village, where she became close to [[Eugene O'Neill]], whom she later credited with having produced "an intensification of the religious sense that was in me".<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=44–7}}</ref> She had a love affair of several years with [[Mike Gold]], a radical writer who later became a prominent Communist.<ref name=nytobit/> She maintained friendships with such prominent American [[Communists]] as [[Anna Louise Strong]], and [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]], who became the head of the [[Communist Party USA]].
Initially Day lived a [[Bohemianism|bohemian]] life. In February 1921,<ref>http://ctstatelibrary.org/marriage-records/</ref> after ending an unhappy love affair with Lionel Moise, and having an abortion that was "the great tragedy of her life,"<ref>{{cite book|last=Wright|first=Terrence C.|title=Dorothy Day: An Introduction to Her Life and Thought|year=2018|publisher=Ignatius Press|location=San Francisco|page=19}}</ref> she married Berkeley Tobey in a civil ceremony. She spent the better part of a year with him in Europe, removed from politics, focusing on art and literature, and writing a semi-autobiographical novel, ''The Eleventh Virgin'' (1924), based on her affair with Moise. In its "Epilogue," she tried to draw lessons about the status of women from her experience: "I thought I was a free and emancipated young woman, and found out I wasn't at all ... [F]reedom is just a modernity gown, a new trapping that we women affect to capture the man we want."<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim |title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=56–7}} Tobey later helped to found the [[Literary Guild]].</ref> She later called it a "very bad book."<ref>{{cite book |last=Forest|first=Jim |title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY|page=65}}</ref> The sale of the movie rights to the novel gave her $2,500, and she bought a beach cottage as a writing retreat in [[Staten Island, New York]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim |title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=65–6}}</ref> Soon she found a new lover, Forster Batterham, an activist and biologist, who joined her there on weekends. She lived there from 1925 to 1929, entertaining friends and enjoying a romantic relationship that foundered when she took passionately to motherhood and religion.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim |title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY|page=67ff.}}</ref>
Day, who had thought herself sterile following her abortion, was elated to find she was pregnant in mid-1925, while Batterham dreaded fatherhood. While she visited her mother in Florida, separating from Batterham for several months, she intensified her exploration of Catholicism. When she returned to Staten Island, Batterham found her increasing devotion, attendance at Mass, and religious reading incomprehensible. Soon after the birth of their daughter Tamar Teresa, on March 4, 1926, Day encountered a local Catholic [[Religious Sister]], Sister Aloysia, [[Sisters of Charity of New York|S.C.]],<ref>{{cite journal|work=The Catholic Worker|first=Dorothy|last=Day|title=On Pilgrimage|date=May 1978|page=2}}</ref> and with her help educated herself in the Catholic faith, and had her baby baptized in July 1927. Batterham refused to attend the ceremony, and his relationship with Day became increasingly unbearable, as her desire for marriage in the Church confronted his antipathy to organized religion, Catholicism most of all. After one last fight in late December, Day refused to allow him to return. On December 28, she had herself baptized with Sister Aloysia as her godparent.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=74–86}} Her baptism was ''[[Conditional baptism|conditional]]'', because she had already been baptized in the Episcopal Church.</ref><ref>A Russian neighbor's sister had named her daughter Tamar, and Day was impressed by St. [[Teresa of Avila]], whose biography she had recently read. {{cite book|last=Miller|first=William D.|title=Dorothy Day: A Biography|publisher=Harper & Row|location=NY|year=1982|page=184}}</ref>
In the summer of 1929, to put the situation with Batterham behind her, Day accepted a job writing film dialogue for [[Pathé|Pathé Motion Pictures]], and moved to Los Angeles with Tamar. A few months later, following the 1929 stock market crash, her contract was not renewed. She returned to New York via a sojourn in Mexico, and a family visit in Florida. Day supported herself as a journalist, writing a gardening column for the local paper, the ''[[Staten Island Advance]]'', and features articles and book reviews for several Catholic publications, like ''[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Forest |first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=90–95 }}</ref><ref>Patrick Jordan, ed., ''Dorothy Day: Writings from Commonweal'' [1929-1973] (Liturgical Press, 2002), 1-55</ref>
It was during one of her assignments for The Commonweal in Washington, D.C. when she decided to take a greater role in social activism and Catholicism. During the hunger strikes in D.C. in December 1932, she noted that she was filled with pride watching the marchers, but she couldn't do much with her conversion. She writes in her autobiography: "I could write, I could protest, to arouse the conscience, but where was the Catholic leadership in the gathering of bands of men and women together, for the actual works of mercy that the comrades had always made part of their technique in reaching the workers?" Later, she visited the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in northeast D.C. to offer a prayer to find a way to use her gifts and talents to help her fellow workers and the poor.<ref>{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Long Loneliness: the autobiography of Dorothy Day|year=1981|publisher=Harper & Row|location=San Francisco|pages=165–166}}</ref>
===The Catholic Worker Movement=== In 1932, Day met [[Peter Maurin]], the man she always credited as the founder of the movement with which she is identified. Maurin, a [[France|French]] immigrant and something of a vagabond, had entered the [[Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools|Brothers of the Christian Schools]] in his native France, before emigrating, first to Canada, then to the United States. Despite his lack of formal education, Maurin was a man of deep intellect and decidedly strong views. He had a vision of social justice and its connection with the poor, which was partly inspired by St. [[Francis of Assisi]]. He had a vision of action based on a sharing of ideas and subsequent action by the poor themselves. Maurin was deeply versed in the writings of the [[Church Fathers]] and the [[papal]] documents on social matters that had been issued by [[Pope Leo XIII]] and his successors. Maurin provided Day with the grounding in Catholic theology of the need for social action they both felt. Years later Day described how Maurin also broadened her knowledge by bringing "a digest of the writings of Kropotkin one day, calling my attention especially to ''Fields, Factories, and Workshops''. Day observed: "I was familiar with Kropotkin only through his ''Memoirs of a Revolutionist,'' which had originally run serially in the ''Atlantic Monthly.'' She wrote: "Oh, far day of American freedom, when Karl Marx could write for the morning ''Tribune'' in New York, and Kropotkin could not only be published in the ''Atlantic,'' but be received as a guest into the homes of New England Unitarians, and in Jane Addams' Hull House in Chicago!"<ref>''Loaves and Fishes,'' 1983 reprint, pp. 13-14.</ref> The French models and literature Maurin drew to Day's attention are of particular interest.<ref>http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/1474225X.2013.780400</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Dorothy Day's social Catholicism: the formative French influences|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/1474225X.2013.780400|journal = International journal for the Study of the Christian Church|date = May 1, 2013|issn = 1474-225X|pages = 96–110|volume = 13|issue = 2|doi = 10.1080/1474225X.2013.780400|first = Robert|last = Atkins}}</ref>
The Catholic Worker movement started when the first issue of the ''[[Catholic Worker]]'' appeared on May 1, 1933, priced at one cent, and published continuously since then. It was aimed at those suffering the most in the depths of the Great Depression, "those who think there is no hope for the future", and announced to them that "the Catholic Church has a social program...there are men of God who are working not only for their spiritual but for their material welfare." It accepted no advertising and did not pay its staff.<ref name="Webb"/> Publication of the first issue was supported in part by a $1 donation from [[Sister Peter Claver]], for whom a Catholic Worker house was later named.<ref name="Fielding">{{cite web|last1=Fielding|first1=Rosemary|title=Sister Peter Claver Spent Life Working for Poor and Forgotten|url=http://oldarchive.godspy.com/reviews/Sister-Peter-Claver-Spent-Life-Working-for-Poor-and-Forgotten-by-Rosemary-Fielding.cfm.html|website=GodSpy: Faith at the edge|accessdate=12 June 2016}}</ref>
Like many newspapers of the day, including those for which Day had been writing, it was an unapologetic example of advocacy journalism. It provided coverage of strikes, explored working conditions, especially of women and black workers, and explicated papal teaching on social issues.<ref name="Webb">Sheila Webb, "Dorothy Day and the Early Years of the ''Catholic Worker'': Social Action through the Pages of the Press", in ''U.S. Catholic Historian'', Vol. 21, No. 3, Summer, 2003, 71-80, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25154868 JSTOR], accessed January 30, 2014</ref> Its viewpoint was partisan and stories were designed to move its readers to take action locally, for example, by patronizing laundries recommended by the Laundry Workers' Union. Its advocacy of federal child labor laws put it at odds with the American Church hierarchy from its first issue, but Day censored some of Maurin's attacks on the Church hierarchy and tried to have a collection of the paper's issues presented to [[Pope Pius XI]] in 1935.<ref>Sheila Webb, "Dorothy Day and the Early Years of the ''Catholic Worker'': Social Action through the Pages of the Press", in ''U.S. Catholic Historian'', Vol. 21, No. 3, Summer, 2003, 80-84, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25154868 JSTOR], accessed January 30, 2014</ref>
The paper's principal competitor both in distribution and ideology was the Communist ''[[Daily Worker]]''. Day opposed its atheism, its advocacy of "class hatred" and violent revolution, and its opposition to private property. The first issue of the ''Catholic Worker'' asked: "Is it not possible to be radical and not atheist?" and celebrated its distribution in [[Union Square, Manhattan|Union Square]] on [[International Workers' Day|May Day]] as a direct challenge to the Communists. Day defended government relief programs like the Civilian Conservation Corps that the Communists ridiculed. The ''Daily Worker'' responded by mocking the ''Catholic Worker'' for its charity work and for expressing sympathy for landlords when calling evictions morally wrong. In this fight, the Church hierarchy backed Day's movement and ''[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]'', a Catholic journal that expressed a wide range of viewpoints, said that Day's background positioned her well for her mission: "There are few laymen in this country who are so completely conversant with Communist propaganda and its exponents."<ref>Sheila Webb, "Dorothy Day and the Early Years of the ''Catholic Worker'': Social Action through the Pages of the Press", in ''U.S. Catholic Historian'', Vol. 21, No. 3, Summer, 2003, 84-8, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25154868 JSTOR], accessed January 30, 2014</ref>
Over several decades, the ''Catholic Worker'' attracted such writers and editors as [[Michael Harrington]], [[Ammon Hennacy]], [[Thomas Merton]], and [[Daniel Berrigan]]. From the publishing enterprise came a "[[house of hospitality]]", a shelter that provided food and clothing to the poor of the Lower East Side and then a series of farms for communal living.<ref name="coles14-15">Coles (1987), pp. 14–15.</ref> The movement quickly spread to other cities in the United States and to Canada and the United Kingdom. More than 30 independent but affiliated Catholic Worker communities had been founded by 1941.<ref name="cwclist">{{cite web | url = http://www.catholicworker.org/communities/commlistall.cfm | title = List of Catholic Worker Communities | publisher = catholicworker.org | accessdate = November 30, 2008 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20081220122836/http://www.catholicworker.org/communities/commlistall.cfm | archivedate = December 20, 2008 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Beginning in 1935, the ''Catholic Worker'' began publishing articles that articulated a rigorous and uncompromising pacifist position, breaking with the traditional Catholic doctrine of [[just war theory]]. The next year, the two sides that fought the [[Spanish Civil War]] roughly approximated two of Day's allegiances, with the Church allied with [[Francisco Franco|Franco]] fighting radicals of many stripes, the ''Catholic'' and the ''worker'' at war with one another. Day refused to follow the Catholic hierarchy in support of Franco against the Republican forces, which were atheist and anticlerical in spirit, led by anarchists and communists (that is, the Republican forces were).<ref name=forest152>{{cite book|last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=152–6}}</ref> She acknowledged the martyrdom of priests and nuns in Spain and said she expected the age of revolution she was living in to require more martyrs:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy |title=Explains CW Stand on Use of Force|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/216.html|accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=September 1938}}</ref> {{quote|We must prepare now for martyrdom–otherwise we will not be ready. Who of us if he were attacked now would not react quickly and humanly against such attack? Would we love our brother who strikes us? Of all at The Catholic Worker how many would not instinctively defend himself with any forceful means in his power? We must prepare. We must prepare now. There must be a disarmament of the heart.}} The paper's circulation fell as many Catholic churches, schools, and hospitals that had previously served as its distribution points withdrew support.<ref name=forest152/> Circulation fell from 150,000 to 30,000.<ref>Sheila Webb, "Dorothy Day and the Early Years of the ''Catholic Worker'': Social Action through the Pages of the Press", in ''U.S. Catholic Historian'', Vol. 21, No. 3, Summer, 2003, 84, [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25154868 JSTOR], accessed January 30, 2014</ref>
In 1938, she published an account of the transformation of her political activism into religiously motivated activism in ''From Union Square to Rome''. She recounted her life story selectively, without providing the details of her early years of "grievous mortal sin" when her life was "pathetic little and mean".<ref>{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=From Union Square to Rome: Chapter 1|year=1938|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/201.html}}</ref> She presented it as an answer to communist relatives and friends who have asked: "How could you become a Catholic?":<ref>{{cite book|last=Day |first=Dorothy |title=From Union Square to Rome: Introduction|year=1938|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/200.html}}</ref> {{quote|What I want to bring out in this book is a succession of events that led me to His feet, glimpses of Him that I received through many years which made me feel the vital need of Him and of religion. I will try to trace for you the steps by which I came to accept the faith that I believe was always in my heart.}} The Cardinal's Literature Committee of the New York Archdiocese recommended it to Catholic readers.<ref>{{cite news |title=Catholic Readers Get List of Books|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1939/04/02/95769927.pdf|accessdate=January 27, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=April 2, 1939}} Dorothy Day, ''From Union Square to Rome'', Silver Spring, MD: Preservation of the Faith Press, 1938</ref>
===Activism=== In the early 1940s she affiliated with the [[Order of St. Benedict|Benedictines]], professing as an [[Oblate#Secular oblates|oblate]] of [[St. Procopius Abbey]] in 1955. This gave her a spiritual practice and connection that sustained her throughout the rest of her life. She was briefly a postulant in the Fraternity of Jesus Caritas, which was inspired by the example of [[Charles de Foucauld]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Merriman|first=Bridget O'Shea|title=Searching for Christ: The Spirituality of Dorothy Day|year=1994 |publisher=University of Notre Dame Press |location=Notre Dame, IN|pages=100–107, 124–127}}</ref> Day felt unwelcome there and disagreed with how meetings were run. When she withdrew as a candidate for the Fraternity, she wrote to a friend: "I just wanted to let you know that I feel even closer to it all, tho it is not possible for me to be a recognized 'Little Sister,' or formally a part of it".<ref>''All the Way to Heaven: The Selected Letters of Dorothy Day'', Robert Ellsberg, ed., Milwaukee: Marquette University Press, p. 301</ref>
Day reaffirmed her [[pacifism]] following the U.S. declaration of war in 1941 and urged noncooperation in a speech that day:<ref>December 8, 1941 speech to the Liberal-Socialist Alliance, New York City, quoted in Sandra J. Sarkela, Susan Mallon Ross, Margaret A. Lowe, ''From Megaphones to Microphones: Speeches of American Women, 1920-1960,'' 2003, pp. 191-192</ref> "We must make a start. We must renounce war as an instrument of policy. . . . Even as I speak to you I may be guilty of what some men call treason. But we must reject war. . . . You young men should refuse to take up arms. Young women tear down the patriotic posters. And all of you—young and old—put away your flags." Her January 1942 column was headlined "We Continue Our Christian Pacifist Stand". She wrote:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=Our Country Passes from Undeclared War to Declared War; We Continue Our Christian Pacifist Stand|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/868.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=January 1942}}</ref> {{quote|We are still pacifists. Our manifesto is the Sermon on the Mount, which means that we will try to be peacemakers. Speaking for many of our conscientious objectors, we will not participate in armed warfare or in making munitions, or by buying government bonds to prosecute the war, or in urging others to these efforts.
But neither will we be carping in our criticism. We love our country and we love our President. We have been the only country in the world where men of all nations have taken refuge from oppression. We recognize that while in the order of intention we have tried to stand for peace, for love of our brother, in the order of execution we have failed as Americans in living up to our principles.}} The circulation of the ''Catholic Worker'', following its losses during the Spanish Civil War, had risen to 75,000, but now plummeted again. The closing of many of the movement's houses around the country, as staff left to join the war effort, showed that Day's pacifism had limited appeal even within the Catholic Worker community.<ref>{{cite book |last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY |pages=161–2}}</ref>
On January 13, 1949, unions representing workers at cemeteries managed by the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York|Archdiocese of New York]] went on strike. After several weeks, Cardinal [[Francis Spellman]] used [[lay brother]]s from the local [[Maryknoll]] seminary and then diocesan seminarians under his own supervision to break the strike by digging graves. He called the union action "Communist-inspired". Employees of the ''Catholic Worker'' joined the strikers' picket line, and Day wrote Spellman, telling him he was "misinformed" about the workers and their demands, defending their right to unionize and their "dignity as men", which she deemed far more important than any dispute about wages. She begged him to take the first steps to resolve the dispute: "Go to them, conciliate them. It is easier for the great to give in than the poor." Spellman stood fast until the strike ended on March 11 when the union members accepted the Archdiocese's original offer of a 48-hour 6-day work week. Day wrote in the ''Catholic Worker'' in April: "A Cardinal, ill-advised, exercised so overwhelming a show of force against the union of poor working men. There is a temptation of the devil to that most awful of all wars, the war between the clergy and the laity." Years later she explained her stance vis-à-vis Spellman: "[H]e is our chief priest and confessor; he is our spiritual leader–of all of us who live here in New York. But he is not our ruler." On March 3, 1951, the Archdiocese ordered Day to cease publication or remove the word ''Catholic'' from the name of her publication. She replied with a respectful letter that asserted as much right to publish the ''Catholic Worker'' as the Catholic War Veterans had to their name and their own opinions independent of those of the Archdiocese. The Archdiocese took no action, and later Day speculated that perhaps church officials did not want members of the Catholic Worker movement holding prayer vigils for him to relent: "We were ready to go to St. Patrick's, fill up the Church, stand outside it in prayerful meditation. We were ready to take advantage of America's freedoms so that we could say what we thought and do what we believed to be the right thing to do."<ref>David L. Gregory, "Dorothy Day, Workers' Rights, and Catholic Authenticity", ''Fordham Urban Law Journal'', Vol 26 Issue 5, 1998, 1371-92, [http://ir.lawnet.fordham.edu/ulj/vol26/iss5/2/ available online]</ref>
Her autobiography, ''The Long Loneliness'', was published in 1952 with illustrations by the Quaker [[Fritz Eichenberg]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Fraser|first=C. Gerald|title=Fritz Eichenberg, A Book Illustrator And Educator, 89 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/04/obituaries/fritz-eichenberg-a-book-illustrator-and-educator-89.html |accessdate= January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 4, 1990}}</ref> ''The New York Times'' summarized it a few years later:<ref>{{cite news|title=Paperbacks in Review|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1960/01/17/99850197.pdf |accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=January 17, 1960}}</ref> {{quote|The autobiography, well and thoughtfully told, of a girl with a conventional upstate New York background whose concern for her neighbors, especially the unfortunate, carried her into the women's suffrage movement, socialism, the I.W.W., communism and finally into the Church of Rome, where she became a co-founder of the Catholic Worker Movement.}}
On June 15, 1955, Day joined a group of pacifists in refusing to participate in civil defense drills scheduled that day. Some of them challenged the constitutionality of the law under which they were charged, but Day and six others took the position that their refusal was not a legal dispute but one of philosophy. Day said she was doing "public penance" for the United States' first use of an atom bomb. They pleaded guilty on September 28, 1955, but the judge refused to send them to jail saying "I'm not making any martyrs."<ref>{{cite news|title=7 Pacifists Insist on Guilty Pleas|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1955/09/29/83375308.pdf|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times |date=September 29, 2014}} The statute at issue was the New York State Defense Emergency Act.</ref> She did the same in each of the next five years. In 1958, instead of taking shelter she joined a group picketing the offices of the [[United States Atomic Energy Commission|U.S. Atomic Energy Commission]].<ref>{{cite news|title=9 Pacifists Seized in Defying Alert|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1958/05/07/82687501.pdf|accessdate=January 26, 2014 |newspaper=New York Times|date=May 7, 1958}}</ref> After some years, sentences were suspended, but once she served 30 days in jail.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pacifists' Dissent Backed|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1957/07/30/84915104.pdf |accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=July 30, 1957}}</ref>
In 1956, along with [[David Dellinger]] and [[A. J. Muste]], two veteran allies in the pacifist movement, she helped found ''[[Liberation (magazine)|Liberation]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Michael T.|title=David Dellinger, of Chicago 7, Dies at 88|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/27/us/david-dellinger-of-chicago-7-dies-at-88.html |accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=May 27, 2004}}</ref>
In 1960, she praised [[Fidel Castro]]'s "promise of social justice". She said: "Far better to revolt violently than to do nothing about the poor destitute."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=Letter to an Imprisoned Editor |url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/760.html|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection |date=January 1960}}</ref> Several months later, Day traveled to Cuba and reported her experiences in a four-part series in the ''Catholic Worker''. In the first of these, she wrote: "I am most of all interested in the religious life of the people and so must not be on the side of a regime that favors the extirpation of religion. On the other hand, when that regime is bending all its efforts to make a good life for the people, a naturally good life (on which grace can build) one cannot help but be in favor of the measures taken."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=Pilgrimage to Cuba--Part I |url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/793.html |accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection |date=September 1962}}</ref>
Day hoped that the [[Second Vatican Council]] would endorse nonviolence as a fundamental tenet of Catholic life and denounce nuclear arms, both their use in warfare and the "idea of arms being used as deterrents, to establish a balance of terror".<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage; Good News|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/248.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=December 1965}}</ref> She lobbied bishops in Rome and joined with other women in a ten-day fast.<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage; October First|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/835.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=November 1965}}</ref> She was pleased when the Council in ''[[Gaudium et spes]]'' (1965), its statement on "the Church in the Modern World", said that nuclear warfare was incompatible with traditional Catholic [[just war theory]]: "Every act of war directed to the indiscriminate destruction of whole cities or vast areas with their inhabitants is a crime against God and man, which merits firm and unequivocal condemnation."<ref>Mark and Louis Zwick, "Introduction" to Dorothy Day, ''On Pilgrimage'' (Eerdmans, 1999), p. 51, [https://books.google.com/books?id=F4yZu5yGT5UC&pg=PA51& available online], accessed January 28, 2014</ref>
Day's account of the Catholic Worker movement, ''Loaves and Fishes'', was published in 1963.
Despite her anti-establishment sympathies, Day's judgment of the 60s counterculture was nuanced. She enjoyed it when [[Abbie Hoffman]] told her she was the original [[hippie]], accepting it as a form of tribute to her detachment from materialism.<ref name="bulletin11-29-80"/> At the same time she disapproved of many who called themselves hippies. She described some she encountered in 1969 in Minnesota: "They are marrying young–17 and 18, and taking to the woods up by the Canadian border and building houses for themselves–becoming pioneers again." But she recognized in them the self-indulgence of middle-class affluence, people who had "not known suffering" and lived without principles. She imagined how soldiers returning from Vietnam would want to kill them, but thought what the "flower-people" deserved was "prayer and penance".<ref>Miller, William D. ''Dorothy Day: A Biography''. San Francisco: Harper & Rowe, 1982, p. 491</ref> Day struggled as a leader with influence but without direct authority over the Catholic Worker houses, even the Tivoli Catholic Worker Farm that she visited regularly. She recorded her frustration in her diary: "I have no power to control smoking of pot, for instance, or sexual promiscuity, or solitary sins."<ref name="Duty of Delight, 2011, p. 447">''Duty of Delight'', 2011, p. 447.</ref>
In 1966, Spellman visited U.S. troops in Vietnam at Christmas, where he was reported as saying: "This war in Vietnam is ... a war for civilization." Day authored a response in the January 1967 issue of the ''Catholic Worker'' that avoided direct criticism but cataloged all the war zones Spellman had visited over the years: "It is not just Vietnam, it is South Africa, it is Nigeria, the Congo, Indonesia, all of Latin America." Visiting was "a brave thing to do", she wrote, and asked: "But oh, God, what are all these Americans doing all over the world so far from our own shores?"<ref>{{cite book|last=Roberts |first=Nancy L.|title=Dorothy Day and the Catholic Worker|year=1984|publisher=State Univ of New York Press|page=164 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wx5A4UE05QYC&pg=PA164&}}</ref>
In 1970, at the height of American participation in the [[Vietnam War]], she described [[Ho Chi Minh]] as "a man of vision, as a patriot, a rebel against foreign invaders" while telling a story of a holiday gathering with relatives where one needs "to find points of agreement and concordance, if possible, rather than the painful differences, religious and political."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=January|title=On Pilgrimage; Perkinsville|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/498.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=January 1970}}</ref>
===Later years=== In 1971, Day was awarded the [[Pacem in Terris Award]] of the Interracial Council of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Davenport|Catholic Diocese of Davenport]], Iowa.<ref>{{cite web |title=Pacem In Terris Past Recipients |url=http://www.davenportdiocese.org/socialaction/sapitrecipients.htm#DOROTHY_DAY |publisher=Diocese of Davenport |accessdate=January 26, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725222132/http://www.davenportdiocese.org/socialaction/sapitrecipients.htm#DOROTHY_DAY |archivedate=July 25, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The [[University of Notre Dame]] awarded her its [[Laetare Medal]] in 1972.<ref>{{cite web |title=Laetare Medal Recipients|url=http://archives.nd.edu/research/facts/laetare.html |publisher=University of Notre Dame Archives|accessdate=January 26, 2014}}</ref>
Despite suffering from poor health, Day visited India, where she met [[Mother Teresa]] and saw her work. In 1971, Day visited Poland, the Soviet Union, Hungary, and Romania as part of a group of peace activists, with the financial support of [[Corliss Lamont]], whom she described as a "'pinko' millionaire who lived modestly and helped the Communist Party USA." <ref>''The Duty of Delight,'' 2011, pp. 587-588.</ref> She met with three members of the [[USSR Union of Writers|Writers' Union]] and defended [[Alexander Solzhenitsyn]] against charges that he had betrayed his country. Day informed her readers that:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage: First Visit to Soviet Russia|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/513.html|accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=September 1971}}</ref> {{quote|Solzhenitsin lives in poverty and has been expelled from the Writers Union and cannot be published in his own country. He is harassed continually, and recently his small cottage in the country has been vandalized and papers destroyed, and a friend of his who went to bring some of his papers to him was seized and beaten. The letter Solzhenitsin wrote protesting this was widely printed in the west, and I was happy to see as a result a letter of apology by the authorities in Moscow, saying that it was the local police who had acted so violently.}} Day visited the [[Kremlin]], and she reported: "I was moved to see the names of the Americans, Ruthenberg and Bill Haywood, on the Kremlin Wall in Roman letters, and the name of Jack Reed (with whom I worked on the old ''Masses''), in Cyrillac characters in a flower-covered grave". Ruthenberg was [[C. E. Ruthenberg]], founder of the [[Communist Party USA]]. [[Bill Haywood]] was a key figure in the [[Industrial Workers of the World|IWW]]. Jack Reed was the journalist better known as [[John Reed (journalist)|John Reed]], author of ''[[Ten Days That Shook the World]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy |title=On Pilgrimage: Russia, II: Kremlin Wall|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/515.html|accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=October–November 1971}}</ref>
In 1972, the Jesuit magazine ''[[America (Jesuit magazine)|America]]'' marked her 75th birthday by devoting an entire issue to Day and the Catholic Worker movement. The editors wrote: "By now, if one had to choose a single individual to symbolize the best in the aspiration and action of the American Catholic community during the last forty years, that one person would certainly be Dorothy Day."<ref>{{cite news|last=Krupa|first=Stephen J.|title=Celebrating Dorothy Day|url=http://americamagazine.org/node/145405|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=America|date=August 27, 2001|quote= Dorothy Day remains, at the dawn of the new millennium, the radical conscience of American Catholicism.}}</ref>
Day had supported the work of [[Cesar Chavez]] in organizing California farm laborers from the beginning of his campaign in the mid-1960s. She admired him for being motivated by religious inspiration and committed to nonviolence.<ref>{{cite book |last=Forest|first=Jim|title=All is Grace: A Biography of Dorothy Day|year=2011 |publisher=Orbis Books |location=Maryknoll, NY |pages=252–60}}</ref> In the summer of 1973, she joined [[Cesar Chavez]] in his campaign for farm laborers in the fields of California. She was arrested with other protesters for defying an injunction against picketing<ref>{{cite news |last=Caldwell |first=Earl |title=Picket Shot, Many More Arrested in Grape Strike|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1973/08/03/90461154.pdf |accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=August 3, 1973}}</ref> and spent ten days in jail.<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage |url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/533.html |accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection |date=September 1973}}</ref>
In 1974, Boston's Paulist Center Community named her the first recipient of their Isaac Hecker Award, given to a person or group "committed to building a more just and peaceful world".<ref>{{cite news|last=McElwee|first=Joshua J.|title=LCWR receives Paulist award for social justice work|url=http://ncronline.org/blogs/ncr-today/lcwr-receives-paulist-award-social-justice-work|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=National Catholic Reporter|date=January 28, 2013}}</ref>
Day made her last public appearance at the [[Eucharistic Congress]] held on August 6, 1976, in [[Philadelphia]] at a service honoring the U.S. Armed Forces on the [[United States bicentennial|Bicentennial of the United States]]. She spoke about reconciliation and penance, and castigated the organizers for failing to recognize that for peace activists August 6 is the day the [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|first atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima]], an inappropriate day to honor the military.<ref>Eileen Egan, "Dorothy Day: Pilgrim of Peace", in Patrick G. Coy, ed., ''A Revolution of the Heart: Essays on the Catholic Worker'', pp. 69-71, [https://books.google.com/books?id=4dG87jxGDFcC&pg=PA69& available online]</ref><ref>Nicholas Rademacher, "'To Relate the Eucharist to Real Living': Mother Teresa and Dorothy Day at the Forty-First International Eucharistic Congress, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania", ''U.S. Catholic Historian'', Volume 27, Number 4, Fall 2009, pp. 59-72</ref>
==Death==
Day suffered a heart attack and died on November 29, 1980, at Maryhouse on [[1st Street (Manhattan)|East 3rd Street]] in Manhattan.<ref name=nytobit>{{cite news |first= Alden|last= Whitman|title=Dorothy Day, Outspoken Catholic Activist, Dies at 83 |url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1980/11/30/111818556.pdf |work=New York Times |date= November 30, 1980 |accessdate=January 28, 2014 }}</ref> Cardinal [[Terence Cooke]] greeted her funeral procession at the [[Church of the Nativity (Manhattan)|Church of the Nativity]], the local [[parish church]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Harrington|first=Michael|title=Existential Saint|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/books/existential-saint.html|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 13, 1982}}</ref> Day was buried in the [[Cemetery of the Resurrection]] on [[Staten Island]] just a few blocks from the beachside cottage where she first became interested in Catholicism.<ref>{{cite book|last=Stone|first=Elained Murray|title=Dorothy Day: Champion of the Poor|year=2004|publisher=Paulist Press|location=Mahwah, NJ|page=102|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Gx8oOw9DHQC&pg=PA102&}}</ref> Her gravestone is inscribed with the words ''Deo Gratias''.<ref>[http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pv&GRid=6246009&PIpi=408103 Dorothy Day, Photos], accessed January 26, 2014</ref> Day's daughter Tamar, the mother of nine children, was with her mother when she died, and she and her father joined the funeral procession and attended a later memorial Mass the cardinal celebrated at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Day and Batterham had remained lifelong friends.<ref>{{cite book|last=Riegle|first=Rosalie G.|title=Dorothy Day: Portraits by Those Who Knew Her.|year=2003|publisher=Orbis Books|location=Maryknoll, NY|pages=112–15}} Tamar Teresa Hennessy died in Vermont on March 25, 2008.</ref>
==Legacy==
[[Judith Palache Gregory]] was Day's executor.
Day's papers are housed at [[Marquette University]] along with many records of the Catholic Worker movement.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dorothy Day-Catholic Worker Collection|url=http://www.marquette.edu/library/archives/day.shtml|work=Special Collections & University Archives|publisher=Raynor Memorial Libraries|accessdate=January 26, 2014}}</ref> The ''Catholic Worker'' had a circulation of more than 100,000 for some years, and reported a circulation of under 30,000 in 2013.<ref>Roberts, pp. 179–182; ''Catholic Worker,'' "Statement of Ownership, Management, and Circulation," December 2013, p. 2.</ref>
In May 1983, a pastoral letter issued by the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops|U.S.Conference of Catholic Bishops]], "The Challenge of Peace," noted her role in establishing non-violence as a Catholic principle: "the nonviolent witness of such figures as Dorothy Day and Martin Luther King has had profound impact upon the life of the Church in the United States."<ref>{{cite web|title=The Challenge of Peace: God's Promise and Our Response, May 3, 1983|url=http://old.usccb.org/sdwp/international/TheChallengeofPeace.pdf|publisher=US Conference of Catholic Bishops|accessdate=January 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140124122451/http://old.usccb.org/sdwp/international/TheChallengeofPeace.pdf|archivedate=January 24, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Attempts to preserve the Staten Island beach bungalow at the [[Spanish Camp]] community where she lived for the last decade of her life failed in 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last=Barrett|first=Wayne|title=Sacking a Saint|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2001-05-01/news/sacking-a-saint/full/|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=Village Voice|date=May 1, 2001}} This was not the same bungalow where she was living at the time of her conversion to Catholicism.</ref>
==Beliefs==
===Charity and poverty=== Day struggled to write about poverty most of her life.<ref>{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Faces of Poverty, in Hearing the Call Across Traditions|year=1963|publisher=|page=117|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K7p8X6Lp7bAC&pg=PA117}}</ref> She admired America's efforts to take responsibility through the government, but ultimately felt that charitable works were personal decisions that needed the warmth of an individual.<ref name="Day 1963 120">{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Faces of Poverty, in Hearing the Call Across Traditions|year=1963|publisher=|page=120|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K7p8X6Lp7bAC&pg=PA120}}</ref>
Day also denounced sins against the poor. She said that "depriving the laborer" was a deadly sin,<ref name="Day 1963 120"/> using similar language to the [[Epistle of James]] in the Bible.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic.org/bible/book.php?id=66&bible_chapter=5 |title=James - Chapter 5 |website=Catholic Online |access-date=September 24, 2015 |quote="Can you hear crying out against you the wages which you kept back from the labourers mowing your fields? The cries of the reapers have reached the ears of the Lord Sabaoth."}}</ref> She also said that [[advertising]] men were sinners ("woe to that generation") because they made the poor "willing to sell [their] liberty and honor" to satisfy "paltry desires."<ref name="Day 1963 120"/>
===All men are brothers=== In the ''Catholic Worker'' in May 1951, Day wrote that Marx, Lenin, and Mao Tse-Tung "were animated by the love of brother and this we must believe though their ends meant the seizure of power, and the building of mighty armies, the compulsion of concentration camps, the forced labor and torture and killing of tens of thousands, even millions." She used them as examples because she insisted that the belief that "all men are brothers" required the Catholic to find the humanity in everyone without exception. She explained that she understood the jarring impact of such an assertion:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Incompatibility of Love and Violence|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/232.html| accessdate =January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=May 1951}}</ref> {{quote|Peter Maurin was constantly restating our position, and finding authorities from all faiths, and races, all authorities. He used to embarrass us sometimes by dragging in Marshall Petain and Fr. Coughlin and citing something good they had said, even when we were combating the point of view they were representing. Just as we shock people by quoting Marx, Lenin, Mao-Tse-Tung, or Ramakrishna to restate the case for our common humanity, the brotherhood of man and the fatherhood of God.}}
In 1970, Day emulated Maurin when she wrote:<ref>"On Pilgrimage--Our Spring Appeal," ''Catholic Worker,'' May 1970</ref> {{quote|the two words [anarchist-pacifist] should go together, especially at this time when more and more people, even priests, are turning to violence, and are finding their heroes in [[Camilo Torres Restrepo|Camillo Torres]] among the priests, and Che Guevara among laymen. The attraction is strong, because both men literally laid down their lives for their brothers. "Greater love hath no man than this." "Let me say, at the risk of seeming ridiculous, that the true revolutionary is guided by great feelings of love." Che Guevara wrote this, and he is quoted by Chicano youth in ''El Grito Del Norte''.}}
====Sympathy and Identification with anarchists==== {{Anarchism sidebar}} Day encountered anarchism while studying in university. She read ''The Bomb'' by [[Frank Harris]], a fictionalized biography of one of the [[Haymarket Affair|Haymarket]] anarchists.<ref>{{cite book|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Long Loneliness: the autobiography of Dorothy Day|year=1981|publisher=Harper & Row|location=San Francisco|page=38}}</ref> She discussed anarchy and extreme poverty with Peter Kropotkin.<ref>Miller, William D. (1982). Dorothy Day: A Biography. NY: Harper & Row. pp. 27–8.</ref> After moving to New York, Day studied the anarchism of [[Emma Goldman]] and attended the Anarchists Ball at [[Webster Hall]].<ref name=elie17>Elie (2003), p. 17</ref>
Day was saddened by the executions of the anarchists [[Sacco and Vanzetti]] in 1927. She wrote that when they died, "All the nation mourned." As a Catholic, she felt a sense of solidarity with them, specifically "the very sense of solidarity which made me gradually understand the doctrine of the Mystical Body of Christ whereby we are all members of one another."<ref name=elie57>Elie (2003), p. 57</ref>
Discussing the term ''anarchism'', she wrote: "We ourselves have never hesitated to use the word. Some prefer personalism. But Peter Maurin came to me with Kropotkin in one pocket and St. Francis in the other!"<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage; Small is Beautiful|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/538.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=February 1974}}</ref>
Dorothy Day's [[anarchist]]<ref name="McKay, Iain 2007. pp. 75">McKay, Iain. ''An Anarchist FAQ Volume One''. AK Press. 2007. pp. 75.</ref> [[distributist]] economic views are very similar to the [[anarchist]] [[Proudhon]]'s [[Mutualism (economic theory)|mutualist]] economic theory whom she was influenced by.<ref name="McKay, Iain 2007. pp. 75"/><ref>Day, Dorothy. ''On Pilgrimage.'' Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. 1999. pp. 22, 40.</ref> The influence of the [[anarchists]] [[Proudhon]] and [[Kropotkin]]<ref>Day, Dorothy. ''House of Hospitality''. Our Sunday Visitor Inc. 2015. pp. 41.</ref> also led her to label herself an [[anarchist]]. Dorothy Day states: "An anarchist then as I am now, I have never used the vote that the women won by their demonstrations before the White House during that period.".<ref>Terrell, Brian. ''Dorothy Day's anarchism is the antidote to disappointing political system''. People: NCRonline.org. April 19, 2016. Retrieved July 21, 2018 from: https://www.ncronline.org/blogs/ncr-today/dorothy-days-anarchism-antidote-disappointing-political-system</ref>
Day explained that anarchists accepted her as someone who shared the values of their movement "[b]ecause I have been behind bars in police stations, houses of detention, jails and prison farms, ... eleven times, and have refused to pay Federal income taxes and have never voted", but were puzzled by what they saw as her "Faith in the monolithic, authoritarian Church". She reversed the viewpoint and ignored their professions of atheism. She wrote: "I in turn, can see Christ in them even though they deny Him, because they are giving themselves to working for a better social order for the wretched of the earth."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage; A Hard Job|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/540.html|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=May 1974}}</ref>
====Sympathy with communists==== In the first years of the ''Catholic Worker'', Day provided a clear statement of how her individualism contrasted with communism:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=A Restatement of C. W. Aims and Ideals |url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/300.html |accessdate=March 30, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection |date=May 1936}}</ref> {{quote|We believe in widespread private property, the de-proletarianizing of our American people. We believe in the individual owning the means of production, the land and his tools. We are opposed to the "finance capitalism" so justly criticized and condemned by Karl Marx but we believe there can be a Christian capitalism as there can be a Christian Communism.}} She also stated: "To labor is to pray -- that is the central point of the Christian doctrine of work. Hence, it is that while both Communism and Christianity are moved by 'compassion for the multitude,' the object of communism is to make the poor richer but the object of Christianity is to make the rich poor and the poor holy."<ref>(September 1946) "The Church and Work," ''Catholic Worker.''</ref> In November 1949, in the course of explaining why she had protested the recent [[Smith Act trials of Communist Party leaders#1949 trial|denial of bail to several Communists]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Porter|first=Russel|title=Law Change Cited|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1949/10/22/86787184.pdf|accessdate=January 28, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=October 22, 1949}}</ref> she wrote: "[L]et it be remembered that I speak as an ex-Communist and one who has not testified before Congressional Committees, nor written works on the Communist conspiracy. I can say with warmth that I loved the [communist] people I worked with and learned much from them. They helped me to find God in His poor, in His abandoned ones, as I had not found Him in Christian churches."<ref name=beyondpolitics>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=Beyond Politics|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/166.html|accessdate=March 30, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=November 1949}}</ref> She identified points on which she agreed with the communists: "from each according to his ability, to each according to his need" and the "withering away of the State." Others she added with qualifications: "the communal aspect of property as stressed by the early Christians". And she identified differences: "we disagree over and over again with the means chosen to reach their ends". She agreed that "Class war is a fact and one does not need to advocate it", but posed the question of how to respond:<ref name=beyondpolitics/> {{quote|The Communists point to it as forced upon them, and say that when it comes they will take part in it, and in their plans they want to prepare the ground, and win as many as possible to their point of view and for their side. And where will we be on that day? ... [W]e will inevitably be forced to be on their side, physically speaking. But when it comes to activity, we will be pacifists, I hope and pray, non-violent resisters of aggression, from whomever it comes, resisters to repression, coercion, from whatever side it comes, and our activity will be the works of mercy. Our arms will be the love of God and our brother.}}
In regard to Fidel Castro's Cuba, she wrote in July 1961: "We are on the side of the revolution. We believe there must be new concepts of property, which is proper to man, and that the new concept is not so new. There is a Christian communism and a Christian capitalism.... We believe in farming communes and cooperatives and will be happy to see how they work out in Cuba.... God bless Castro and all those who are seeing Christ in the poor. God bless all those who are seeking the brotherhood of man because in loving their brothers they love God even though they deny Him."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=About Cuba |url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/246.html |accessdate=March 30, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection |date=July 1961}}</ref> It was only in December 1961 that Castro, who had repeatedly repudiated communism in the past, openly declared that his movement was not simply socialist, but communist.<ref>Leycester Coltman, ''The Real Fidel Castro'' (New Haven and London: Yale University Press, 2008), p. 262.</ref>
===Catholic Church property=== [[Bill Kauffman]] of ''[[The American Conservative]]'' wrote of Day: "The Little Way. That is what we seek. That—contrary to the ethic of personal parking spaces, of the dollar-sign god—is the American way. Dorothy Day kept to that little way, and that is why we honor her. She understood that if small is not always beautiful, at least it is always human."<ref>[[Rod Dreher|Dreher, Rod]] (June 5, 2006) [http://www.amconmag.com/article/2006/jun/05/00029/ All-American Anarchists], ''[[The American Conservative]]''</ref>
Day's belief in smallness also applied to the property of others, including the Catholic Church, as when she wrote: "Fortunately, the Papal States were wrested from the Church in the last century, but there is still the problem of investment of papal funds. It is always a cheering thought to me that if we have good will and are still unable to find remedies for the economic abuses of our time, in our family, our parish, and the mighty church as a whole, God will take matters in hand and do the job for us. When I saw the Garibaldi mountains in British Columbia . . . I said a prayer for his soul and blessed him for being the instrument of so mighty a work of God. May God use us!"<ref>"Hutterite Communities," ''Catholic Worker'' (July–August 1969)</ref>
Jesuit priest Daniel Lyons "called Day 'an apostle of pious oversimplification.' He said that the ''Catholic Worker'' 'often distorted beyond recognition' the position of the Popes".<ref>{{cite book|last=Roberts |first=Nancy L.|title=Dorothy Day and the Catholic Worker|year=1984|publisher=State Univ of New York Press|page=161 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wx5A4UE05QYC&pg=PA161&}}</ref>
===Catholic orthodoxy=== Day wrote in one of her memoirs: "I had a conversation with John Spivak, the Communist writer, a few years ago, and he said to me, "How can you believe? How can you believe in the Immaculate Conception, in the Virgin birth, in the Resurrection?" I could only say that I believe in the Roman Catholic Church and all she teaches. I have accepted Her authority with my whole heart. At the same time I want to point out to you that we are taught to pray for final perseverance. We are taught that faith is a gift, and sometimes I wonder why some have it and some do not. I feel my own unworthiness and can never be grateful enough to God for His gift of faith."<ref>''From Union Square to Rome'' (1938), pp. 144-45; [[John L. Spivak|John Spivak]] was a leftist and journalist.</ref>
Day's commitment to Church teaching is illustrated by an encounter she had with [[Daniel Berrigan|Fr. Daniel Berrigan, S.J.]] while on a Catholic Worker farm in New York. Berrigan was about to say Mass for the community vested only in a [[stole (vestment)|stole]]. Day insisted that he put on the proper vestments before he began. When Berrigan fussed about the foolishness of the law regarding liturgical attire, Day responded, "On this farm, we obey the laws of the Church." He relented and said the Mass fully vested.<ref name="Becker1997">{{cite book|last1=Becker|first1=Joseph|title=The Re-Formed Jesuits|date=1997|publisher=Ignatius Press|location=San Francisco|isbn=0-89870-627-0|page=82}}</ref>
===The laity=== In response to press coverage in 1964 of an ongoing dispute between Cardinal [[James Francis McIntyre|James McIntyre]] of [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Los Angeles|Los Angeles]] and some of his priests, who criticized him for a lack of leadership on civil rights,<ref>{{cite news|title=Story Priest Disputes Coast Cardinal|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1964/12/29/93225028.pdf|accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=December 29, 1964}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Priest Who Assailed Cardinal McIntyre Talks at Chancery|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1964/06/17/archives/priest-who-assailed-cardinal-mcintyre-talks-at-chancery.html |accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 17, 1964}}</ref> Day authored an essay on the laity's responsibility to act independently of the church hierarchy. When the ''Catholic Worker'' during World War II, she wrote, took a pacifist stance, "Bishop McIntyre merely commented ... 'We never studied these things much in the seminary' ... adding doubtfully, 'There is the necessity of course to inform one's conscience.' " For that attitude, Day added, "our shepherds are to be reproached, that they have not fed their sheep these strong meats ... capable of overcoming all obstacles in their advance to that kind of society where it easier to be good." She instructed her readers: "Let Catholics form their associations, hold their meetings in their own homes, or in a hired hall, or any place else. Nothing should stop them. Let the controversy come out into the open in this way."<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=The Case of Cardinal McIntyre|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/196.html|accessdate=January 31, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=July–August 1964}}</ref>
===Sex=== In September 1963, Day discussed pre-marital sex in her column, warning against those who portrayed it as a form of freedom: "The wisdom of the flesh is treacherous indeed." She described herself as "a woman who must think in terms of the family, the need of the child to have both mother and father, who believes strongly that the home is the unit of society" and wrote that:<ref>{{cite news|last=Day|first=Dorothy|title=On Pilgrimage: Cuba and Sex|url=http://dorothyday.catholicworker.org/articles/806.html|accessdate=February 2, 2014|newspaper=Dorothy Day Collection|date=September 1963}}</ref> {{quote|When sex is treated lightly, as a means of pleasure ... it takes on the quality of the demonic, and to descend into this blackness is to have a foretaste of hell... There is no such thing as seeing how far one can go without being caught, or how far one can go without committing mortal sin.}} In 1968, Day wrote again about sex—this time in her diary—in response to the criticisms of Stanley Vishnewski (and other coworkers at the Tivoli farm) that she had "no power" over marijuana smoking "or sexual promiscuity, or solitary sins."<ref name="Duty of Delight, 2011, p. 447"/> The situation continued to remain a problem, as Day also documented in her diary:<ref>''Duty of Delight'' (2011) pp. 522-523.</ref>
{{quote|For some weeks now my problem is this: What to do about the open immorality (and of course I mean sexual morality) in our midst. It is like the last times—there is nothing hidden that shall not be revealed. But when things become a matter for open discussion, what about example set, that most powerful of all teachers. We have with us now a beautiful woman with children whose husband has taken up with a seventeen-year-old, is divorcing her and starting on a new marriage. She comes to us as to a refuge where by working for others in our community of fifty or more, she can forget once in a while her human misery. . . . We have one young one, drunken, promiscuous, pretty as a picture, college educated, mischievous, able to talk her way out of any situation—so far. She comes to us when she is drunk and beaten and hungry and cold and when she is taken in, she is liable to crawl into the bed of any man on the place. We do not know how many she has slept with on the farm. What to do? What to do?}}
==Cause for sainthood== A proposal for Day's [[canonization]] was put forth publicly by the [[Claretian Missionaries]] in 1983. At the request of [[Cardinal (Catholic Church)|Cardinal]] [[John Joseph O'Connor|John J. O'Connor]], head of the diocese in which she lived, in March 2000 [[Pope John Paul II]] granted the [[Archdiocese of New York]] permission to open her cause, allowing her to be called a "[[Servant of God]]" in the eyes of the [[Catholic Church]]. As [[canon law (Catholic Church)|canon law]] requires, the Archdiocese of New York submitted this cause for the endorsement of the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]], which it received in November 2012.<ref>{{cite web|work=Catholic New Service |url=http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/1204800.htm |archive-url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121207032158/http://www.catholicnews.com/data/stories/cns/1204800.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 7, 2012 |title=US bishops endorse sainthood cause of Catholic Worker's Dorothy Day |date=November 13, 2012 |accessdate=December 1, 2012 }}</ref> Some members of the Catholic Worker Movement objected to the canonization process as a contradiction of Day's own values and concerns.<ref>{{cite news | title = Some followers question Day sainthood | url = http://catholic-sf.org/ns.php?newsid=16&id=60819 | work = Catholic San Francisco | date = December 5, 2012 | accessdate = January 27, 2014 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140220032443/http://catholic-sf.org/ns.php?newsid=16&id=60819 | archivedate = February 20, 2014 | df = mdy-all }}</ref>
Pope [[Benedict XVI]], on February 13, 2013, in the closing days of his papacy, cited Day as an example of conversion. He quoted from her writings and said: "The journey towards faith in such a secularized environment was particularly difficult, but Grace acts nonetheless."<ref>{{cite news|last=McElwee|first=Joshua J.|title=Looking to legacy, pope mentions Dorothy Day|url=http://ncronline.org/blogs/ncr-today/looking-legacy-pope-mentions-dorothy-day|accessdate=January 26, 2014|newspaper=National Catholic Reporter|date=February 13, 2013}}</ref><!-- BEFORE ADDING COMMENTS BY POPE FRANCIS ON September 24, 2015, READ THE ENTIRE ARTICLE. IT IS DISCUSSED ELSEWHERE. -->
==Posthumous recognition== *An independent film about Dorothy Day called ''[[Entertaining Angels: The Dorothy Day Story]]'' was produced in 1996. Day was portrayed by [[Moira Kelly]], and [[Peter Maurin]] was portrayed by [[Martin Sheen]].<ref>{{IMDb title|0426883|Entertaining Angels|1996}}</ref> *A full-length documentary about Day, ''Dorothy Day: Don't Call Me a Saint'', premiered in 2005. It was shown at the 2006 [[Tribeca Film Festival]].<ref>{{IMDb title|0795373|Dorothy Day: Don't Call Me a Saint|2006}}</ref> *Day's diaries and letters were edited by [[Robert Ellsberg]] and published by [[Marquette University Press]] in 2008 and 2010, respectively.<ref>[http://www.marquette.edu/mupress/ ''The Duty of Delight'']</ref> *In 1992, Day received the Courage of Conscience Award from the Peace Abbey.<ref name="peaceabbey">{{cite web|url=http://www.peaceabbey.org/cofc-award/award-recipients/ |title=The Peace Abbey Courage of Conscience Award Recipients |publisher=The Peace Abbey |accessdate=October 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140610041225/http://www.peaceabbey.org/cofc-award/award-recipients/ |archivedate=June 10, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> *In 2001, Day was inducted into the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]] in [[Seneca Falls (town), New York|Seneca Falls, New York]].<ref name="nwhf">{{cite web |url= http://greatwomen.org/women.php?action=viewone&id=184/ |title= National Women's Hall of Fame, Women of the Hall, Dorothy Day |publisher= National Women's Hall of Fame |accessdate = January 26, 2014}}</ref> *Dormitories at [[Lewis University]] in Romeoville, Illinois, University of Scranton in Scranton, Pennsylvania, and [[Loyola University Maryland|Loyola University, Maryland]], are named in her honor, as is the campus ministry at [[Xavier University]]. *A professorship at [[St. John's University (Jamaica, NY)|St. John's University]] School of Law is named in her honor.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://stjohns.edu/academics/graduate/law/faculty/profiles/Gregory |title = David L. Gregory | publisher = stjohns.edu | accessdate = February 25, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stjohns.edu/academics/graduate/law/news/Faculty/pr_law_060829.sju |title=David L. Gregory Appointed Dorothy Day Professor of Law |publisher=stjohns.org |accessdate=February 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930193729/http://www.stjohns.edu/academics/graduate/law/news/Faculty/pr_law_060829.sju |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> *At Marquette University, a dormitory floor bearing Day's name has been reserved for those drawn to social justice issues. *The Office of Service and Justice at [[Fordham University]] bears her name, at both of the university's campuses. *[[Saint Peter's University|Saint Peter's College]] of [[Jersey City, New Jersey]], named its Political Science Office the Dorothy Day House. *Broadway Housing Communities, a supportive housing project in New York City, opened the Dorothy Day Apartment Building at 583 Riverside Drive in 2003.<ref>[http://www.broadwayhousing.org Broadway Housing Communities]</ref> * On September 24, 2015, [[Pope Francis]] became the first pope to address a joint meeting of the [[United States Congress]]. Day was one of four Americans mentioned by the Pope in his speech to the joint session that included [[Abraham Lincoln]], [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] and [[Thomas Merton]]. He said of Day: "Her social activism, her passion for justice and for the cause of the oppressed, were inspired by the Gospel, her faith, and the example of the saints."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w2.vatican.va/content/francesco/en/speeches/2015/september/documents/papa-francesco_20150924_usa-us-congress.html |date=September 24, 2015 |accessdate=September 24, 2015 |title=Address of the Holy Father |website=The Vatican |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925134238/http://w2.vatican.va/content/francesco/en/speeches/2015/september/documents/papa-francesco_20150924_usa-us-congress.html |archivedate=September 25, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref> * [[DC Comics]] character [[Leslie Thompkins]] is, according to her creator [[Denny O'Neil]], based on Day.<ref>{{cite news | publisher = ComixMix | title =Dennis O’Neil: Gotham’s Doctor, Batman’s Saint | url = http://www.comicmix.com/2015/02/19/dennis-oneil-gothams-doctor-batmans-saint/ | accessdate = May 7, 2016 | first = Dennis | last = O'Neil | date =February 19, 2015}}</ref> * Indie rock band, The Chairman Dances, included a song for Day and [[Peter Maurin]] on their 2016 album, ''Time Without Measure''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://store.thechairmandances.com/album/time-without-measure|title=Time Without Measure by The Chairman Dances|last=|first=|date=|website=Bandcamp|access-date=}}</ref> The song premiered on [[PopMatters]] on July 22, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/post/the-chairman-dances-dorothy-day-and-peter-maurin-audio-premiere/|title=The Chairman Dances - "Dorothy Day and Peter Maurin" (audio) (premiere)|last=|first=|date=|website=PopMatters|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160723160724/http://www.popmatters.com/post/the-chairman-dances-dorothy-day-and-peter-maurin-audio-premiere/|archive-date=2016-07-23|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> * [[Dorothy Day homeless shelter|Dorothy Day Center]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota]], a [[homeless shelter]] managed by [[Catholic Charities USA|Catholic Charities]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.mprnews.org/story/2017/01/12/higher-ground-shelter-opens|title=Higher Ground, new homeless shelter, open for first night in St. Paul|last=Collins|first=Jon|access-date=2017-08-24}}</ref>
